Article.ArticleTitle: Validation of visual analogue scale for anxiety (VAS-A) in preanesthesia evaluation.

AbstractText: Anxiety is a relevant but still underscored perioperative problem. The Visual Analogue Scale for Anxiety (VAS-A) seems to be effective, fast and manageable, but has not been fully validated yet. The aim of this study is to validate VAS-A comparing it to, Corah's Dental Anxiety Scale (CDAS) Spielberger's State Trait Anxiety Inventory (STAI) and Beck Depression Inventory (BDI).

One hundred consecutive patients (38 males and 62 females, median age 49 years) submitted to oral surgery filled out the VAS-A, CDAS, STAI forms Y1 and Y2, and BDI at preoperative examination; the order of administration of tests was randomized.

VAS-A score was significantly correlated to CDAS (P<0.0001), STAI-Y1 (P<0.0001), STAI-Y2 (P<0.002) but not to BDI (P=0.18). ROC curve analysis suggested VAS-A equal to 46 mm as threshold for anxiety when using STAI Y1 equal to 40 as reference cutoff.

Our study confirms that VAS-A is a reliable indicator of preoperative anxiety and may detect patients with depressive symptoms also. Values of VAS-A around 50 mm are a reliable threshold for a clinically meaningful level of preoperative anxiety.
